awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Genome-Scale Phylogeographic Analysis of Desmognathus Salamanders
awd_abstract_narration:
The Dusky Salamanders, genus Desmognathus, are one of the most diverse and abundant animals in the eastern forests of the United States. They are classic study organisms for ecology and behavior. Along with frogs and other salamanders worldwide, they are also disappearing at an alarming rate, possibly due to factors such as habitat loss, infectious diseases, and other environmental stresses. Despite their visibility and imperilment, we know little about their genetic diversity and evolutionary history. While there are only 21 currently named species, recent work using DNA sequencing has revealed at least 45 potential species, which would more than double the size of the group. This research will reveal the true diversity of the group, providing a future platform for ecological and evolutionary studies of Desmognathus, and guiding conservation-management decisions for this imperiled group of aquatic vertebrates. Broader impacts will include a K-12 teaching module for understanding forest ecology, centered on salamanders, and updated species accounts for local wildlife-management authorities. This will be invaluable for understanding the biodiversity heritage of the United States.

With an exhaustive "ecodrainage" sampling technique, this research will analyze >7,000 samples from nearly every known Desmognathus population. The study will use next-generation genomic sequencing of DNA to understand the true genetic diversity of the group. These data will allow researchers to understand the evolutionary history of divergence, hybridization, and species boundaries from a genetic perspective, using modern species-delimitation methods. Many species are also difficult to distinguish by eye. Thus, this research will complement the genetic perspective with 3-dimensional geometric morphometric analyses of size and shape, to reveal the subtle but significant morphological differences between populations. Overall, this research will generate a robust and fully-sampled estimate of the true number of Desmognathus species, their morphological variation for identifying them in the field, and their geographic range. This research will likely yield an increased number of Desmognathus species, while also showing a complex history of introgression, hybridization, and incomplete ecological speciation in the group.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this award has revealed a vast underestimation of salamander biodiversity in the eastern United States, specifically within the genus Desmognathus. Long noted for its morphological crypsis and early indications of substantial genetic diversity, it has historically been thought to contain only 22 species. Our genome-scale datasets have revealed the presence of at least 49 species-level lineages, many of which are now waiting to be described as species new to science. Many of these populations are classic study organisms in physiology, ecology, evolution, and behavior, and understanding their taxonomy and evolutionary history is crucial to contextualize over a century of research,

 

While the temperate ecosystems of the eastern US have long been regarded as a biodiversity hotspot, our research reveals that the true diversity may be undercounted by a factor of 2-3x, at least in some groups. While many of the new species are concentrated in the southern Appalachian Mountains, we discovered high amounts of cryptic diversity in other regions, such as the Piedmont and Coastal Plain in both Atlantic and Gulf river drainages. A unique lineage even occurs west of the Mississippi River in Texas and Louisiana. This broad distribution of cryptic diversity reveals the impact of numerous processes, such as glaciation and refugia, headwater drainage capture, and sea level changes on speciation in the Nearctic.

 

Furthermore, the genomic scale of our dataset reveals the puzzling persistence of gene flow after speciation, with hybridization occurring across multiple geographic, phylogenetic, and temporal scales. This introgression results in the most accurate portrayal of Desmognathus relationships as a network, with many deep-time reticulations and recent instances of admixture. The boundaries of many species are confounded by genetic exchange and mitochondrial capture, even as they appear to maintain geographic and genealogical cohesiveness. Our understanding of speciation genomics may be significantly enhanced by future studies on hybrid zones in the group.

 

Overall, this project has supported at least 4 major publications, with several more in preparation, including the resurrection or description of the 27 newly uncovered species-level taxa. Perhaps most importantly, the grant funded the training of numerous researchers at the K-12, undergrad, graduate, and post-doctoral level, including many from under-represented groups in STEM. We are working with state and local agencies and Indigenous peoples to help inform conservation management strategies for this highly diverse and yet potentially imperiled group of salamanders. These preliminary results will act as a foundation for future training, conservation, and research on the still incompletely understood biodiversity of the United States.
